messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 64 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Approximation of the Diagonal of a Laplacian‚Äôs Pseudoinverse for Complex Network Analysis

Paper Abstract: Abstract The ubiquity of massive graph data sets in numerous applications requires fast algorithms for extracting knowledge from these data. We are motivated here by three electrical measures for the analysis of large small-world graphs G=(V,E)ùê∫ùëâùê∏G=(V,E) ‚Äì i. e., graphs with diameter in ùí™‚Äã(log‚Å°|V|)ùí™ùëâ\mathcal{O}(\log|V|), which are abundant in complex network analysis. From a computational point of view, the three measures have in common that their crucial component is the diagonal of the graph Laplacian‚Äôs pseudoinverse, ùêã‚Ä†superscriptùêã‚Ä†\mathbf{L}^{\dagger}. Computing diag‚Å°(ùêã‚Ä†)diagsuperscriptùêã‚Ä†\operatorname{diag}(\mathbf{L}^{\dagger}) exactly by pseudoinversion, however, is as expensive as dense matrix multiplication ‚Äì and the standard tools in practice even require cubic time. Moreover, the pseudoinverse requires quadratic space ‚Äì hardly feasible for large graphs. Resorting to approximation by, e. g., using the Johnson-Lindenstrauss transform, requires the solution of ùí™‚Äã(log‚Å°|V|/œµ2)ùí™ùëâsuperscriptitalic-œµ2\mathcal{O}(\log|V|/\epsilon^{2}) Laplacian linear systems to guarantee a relative error, which is still very expensive for large inputs. In this paper, we present a novel approximation algorithm that requires the solution of only one Laplacian linear system. The remaining parts are purely combinatorial ‚Äì mainly sampling uniform spanning trees, which we relate to diag‚Å°(ùêã‚Ä†)diagsuperscriptùêã‚Ä†\operatorname{diag}(\mathbf{L}^{\dagger}) via effective resistances. For small-world networks, our algorithm obtains a ¬±œµplus-or-minusitalic-œµ\pm\epsilon-approximation with high probability, in a time that is nearly-linear in |E|ùê∏|E| and quadratic in 1/œµ1italic-œµ1/\epsilon. Another positive aspect of our algorithm is its parallel nature due to independent sampling. We thus provide two parallel implementations of our algorithm: one using OpenMP, one MPI + OpenMP. In our experiments against the state of the art, our algorithm (i) yields more accurate approximation results for diag‚Å°(ùêã‚Ä†)diagsuperscriptùêã‚Ä†\operatorname{diag}(\mathbf{L}^{\dagger}), (ii) is much faster and more memory-efficient, and (iii) obtains good parallel speedups, in particular in the distributed setting.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 64 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 64"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "The random walk construction of uniform spanning trees and uniform labelled trees",
        "Graph clustering using effective resistance",
        "Parallel computation of entries of a-1-1{}^{\\mbox{-1}}",
        "Approximation of the diagonal of a laplacian‚Äôs pseudoinverse for complex network analysis, 2020",
        "Guidelines for experimental algorithmics: A case study in network analysis",
        "Randomized algorithms for estimating the trace of an implicit symmetric positive semi-definite matrix",
        "On the architectural requirements for efficient execution of graph algorithms",
        "Estimating the inverse trace using random forests on graphs, 2019",
        "An estimator for the diagonal of a matrix",
        "Computing top-k closeness centrality faster in unweighted graphs",
        "Estimating current-flow closeness centrality with a multigrid laplacian solver",
        "Near linear-work parallel sdd solvers, low-diameter decomposition, and low-stretch subgraphs, 2011",
        "Axioms for centrality",
        "Modern Graph Theory, volume 184 of Graduate Texts in Mathematics",
        "Approximations of the generalized inverse of the graph laplacian matrix",
        "Resistance distance, closeness, and betweenness",
        "Centrality measures based on current flow",
        "Generating random spanning trees",
        "R-mat: A recursive model for graph mining",
        "The electrical resistance of a graph captures its commute and cover times",
        "Solving sdd linear systems in nearly mlog1/2n time",
        "Effective graph resistance",
        "Effective resistance on graphs and the epidemic quasimetric",
        "A stochastic estimator of the trace of the influence matrix for laplacian smoothing splines",
        "Minimizing effective resistance of a graph",
        "Algebraic graph theory, volume 207",
        "Matrix computations",
        "Eigen v3",
        "Efficient algorithms for spanning tree centrality",
        "Pselinv ‚Äì a distributed memory parallel algorithm for selected inversion: The non-symmetric case",
        "Extensions of lipschitz mappings into a hilbert space",
        "A simple, combinatorial algorithm for solving sdd systems in nearly-linear time",
        "Resistance distance",
        "A nearly-m log n time solver for SDD linear systems",
        "Approaching optimality for solving SDD linear systems",
        "Combinatorial preconditioners and multilevel solvers for problems in computer vision and image processing",
        "KONECT: the koblenz network collection",
        "Approximate gaussian elimination for laplacians - fast, sparse, and simple",
        "Sparsified cholesky and multigrid solvers for connection laplacians",
        "Current flow group closeness centrality for complex networks?",
        "Kirchhoff index as a measure of edge centrality in weighted networks: Nearly linear time algorithms",
        "Lean algebraic multigrid (LAMG): Fast graph laplacian linear solver",
        "Random walks on graphs: A survey",
        "Challenges in parallel graph processing",
        "Probability on Trees and Networks",
        "Fast computation of empirically tight bounds for the diameter of massive graphs",
        "Spanning Edge Centrality: Large-scale Computation and Applications",
        "Practical graph isomorphism",
        "Scaling of random walk betweenness in networks",
        "Networks (2nd Ed.)",
        "Ranking of closeness centrality for large-scale social networks",
        "Pcg: A family of simple fast space-efficient statistically good algorithms for random number generation",
        "An efficient parallel solver for sdd linear systems, 2014",
        "Incremental computation of pseudo-inverse of laplacian",
        "An almost-linear time algorithm for uniform random spanning tree generation",
        "Kernel Methods for Pattern Analysis",
        "Adjustment of an inverse matrix corresponding to a change in one element of a given matrix",
        "Rational approximation to the fermi-dirac function with applications in density functional theory",
        "Graph sparsification by effective resistances",
        "Networkit: A tool suite for large-scale complex network analysis",
        "A probing method for computing the diagonal of a matrix inverse",
        "Pseudoinverse of the laplacian and best spreader node in a network",
        "Generating massive complex networks with hyperbolic geometry faster in practice",
        "Generating random spanning trees more quickly than the cover time"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 64 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Approximation of the Diagonal of a Laplacian‚Äôs Pseudoinverse for Complex Network Analysis, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
